moves.1. d4: A blitz game. My opponent had a higher rating, around 1700. I did not expect to win.
moves.2. Nf3 g6 3. c4 d5: I had no clear ideas here. I just thought of going for something sharp.
moves.5. Nc3 c6 6. b4 a6 7. a4: White is clearly going for a pawn attack on the queen side. At this stage, I decided to leave off trying to counter this, and switch attention to normal development on the king side.
moves.8... Nbd7 9. b5 axb5 10. axb5 Rxa1 11. Q: The queen now has control of the a file, and is contesting the long diagonal. He is on the way to having a spatial advantage on the queen side, but to compensate, black has developed a solid defense on the king side.
moves.13... Qd7 14. Ne5: It now looks like white is developing a threatening attack, but the black defensive structure is solid.
moves.14... Qe6: Primarily defending f7, but also looking at white king
moves.15. e3: Completing the pawn chain and opening the file for white bishop
moves.15... Ne4: At this stage, the knight is the only piece I wanted to move, keeping the king side structure solid and stable.
moves.17. O-O Nd7: A blunder, I think. The knight was alright where it was, but hard to see what would have been a better move.
moves.18. Bg4: Strong check to the queen, winning the knight. I considered resigning.
moves.18... Qf6: Just moving out the way, but moving to a useful square.
moves.19. Bxd7 Bxd7 20. Nxd7 Qf5: Moving to safety, and checking the knight.
moves.21. Ne5 Nd2: The move I should have played earlier, I think. Again, the king side structure is solid. It appeared that there was no piece there which could be moved without creating a weakness. Only the knight was free to move. Here it would move the castle, then move back, threatening check. Just messing around, really.
moves.22. Re1 Ne4 23. Nf3: Defending f2, but creating space for the e5 push
moves.23... e5: Bringing the castle into the game
moves.24. Nxe5: Queen will win back the pawn with tempo
moves.24... Qxf2+ 25. Kh1: I was running out of time. I think I had a little over a minute, whereas white had around five. Nothing to do but to move back.
moves.26. Nf3: Hard to see the point here.
moves.26... Nf2+: Again, just messing around. Again, it seems that this knight is the only piece which can move. All the others are keeping the defensive balance.
moves.27. Kg1 Ng4: Attacking e3, the base of the pawn structure. Black has kept tempo, dictating the pace of the game, and preventing Qa7.
moves.28. Re2: Planning to double up with the Queen? But the pawn is still underdefended.
moves.28... Rxe3 29. Rxe3 Nxe3: Although behind in points, black has compensated with tempo.
moves.30. Qa8+: Easily defended, losing the pawn though.
moves.30... Bf8 31. Qxb7 Qc2: All of a sudden, things are looking dangerous for white. There is no way to save the knight, but more dangerous is the threatened mate on g2, which white appears to have overlooked.
